Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Analog Networking: Distributed Source-Channel Approaches to Delay and Resource Constrained Communications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Severe delay and resource (energy, bandwidth) constraints are typical in emerging communications and networking applications within a variety of scientific and engineering disciplines. This is particularly the case in highly constrained sensor networks. Such applications strongly motivate foregoing the convenience of digital communication and revisiting the potential benefits, and even necessity of analog communication, albeit in the modern context of distributed source-channel coding and routing. Major challenges emerge, including the derivation of a theoretical foundation for analog networking from estimation and information theoretic principles, specializing to a variety of subproblems and networking scenarios involving distributed source-channel coding, and developing effective practical algorithmic approaches, as well as a formidable optimization challenge due to the high complexity of the overall objective function which is literally riddled with poor local optima.

The general analog networking problem is formulated in terms of analog mappings, between source and channel variables at source nodes (encoders), between received and transmitted variables at intermediate network nodes, and between received and reconstruction variables at sink nodes (decoders). Research is pursued along several specific lines of investigation, including derivation of delay-constrained performance bounds and optimality conditions, optimal and low complexity algorithm design, global optimization techniques, analog mappings for distributed source-channel coding, analog multiple descriptions coding, extensions to sources and channels with memory, and optimal routing in an analog network. The effort builds on a body of preliminary work and results, including the necessary conditions for optimality of such mappings in simple settings, iterative algorithms to find locally optimal mappings, as well as a powerful non- convex optimization tool (deterministic annealing), which has been successfully employed in related optimization problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project was focused on theoretical and practical problems involving highly constrained analog networks. Severe delay and resource constraints in emerging communications and networking applications, particularly in the case of sensor networks under extreme power and delay constraints, strongly motivate forgoing the convenience of digital communication and revisiting the potential benefits, and even necessity of analog communication, albeit in the modern context of distributed source-channel coding and routing. The project produced a series of outcomes ranging from the theoretical foundation for the problem and derivation of performance bounds, to the development and verification of powerful optimization methods to approach these bounds in practice, as well as spin-off outcomes that transcend the original problem discipline. 

A main outcome of the project is the theoretical foundation for the general analog networking problem, which was formulated in terms of analog mappings, between source and channel variables at source nodes (encoders), between received and re-transmitted variables at intermediate network nodes, and between received and reconstructed variables at sink nodes (decoders). This enabled the development of a mapping optimization framework that is general, and applicable to a wide variety of networking problems, without recourse to any simplifying assumptions about the underlying distributions, cost functions, parametric form and structure of the mappings. A particularly important outcome is the derivation and implementation of a global optimization framework leveraging the concept of deterministic annealing, which enables the joint optimization of a seemingly intractably complex cost involving a set of mapping functions, while avoiding poor local optima. The approach demonstrably yields considerable performance gains over the existing heuristic methods for a large variety of network settings, including a number of classical networking problems involving distributed source coding, multiple descriptions coding, and coding to exploit decoder side information. Yet another significant outcome of the project is due to the generality of the framework and approaches, which enabled extensions to a broad spectrum of problems outside the primary discipline, with a particularly significant impact on fundamental problems in stochastic and distributed control, wherein decentralized controllers effectively implement analog mappings that must be optimized jointly to achieve the best possible overall performance.

A complementary set of significant theoretical outcomes of the project is due to the derivation of necessary and sufficient conditions for linearity of optimal mappings, with direct implication on general estimation as well as the immediately relevant problem of encoding and decoding mappings in zero delay communications. Beside the obvious theoretical value of the result, it has several significant practical implications, including the ability to ascertain when simpler linear methods can be employed with little to no performance penalty. These linearity conditions were specialized to several other important network settings, providing results for settings of considerable value in sensor networks, and in particular for the classical problem of source estimation through multiple observations corrupted by independent noise, and that of estimation of multiple independent sources corrupted by the same noise. 

Another significant outcome has implications in game theory. The insights obtained on linearity of optimal mappings has inspired interesting and important spinoff results in the game-theoretic area of sensor networks with adversary jammers.
